statements.text: The European Union should become a United States of Europe.
The European Union shouldn't become a United States of Europe.

The development of the European Union since 1945 [1] has been one of the most successful peace projects in history [2]. Developing the EU into a USE will consolidate this effort and ensure lasting peace.

The development of the European Union since 1945 [1] hasn't been one of the most successful peace projects in history [2]. Developing the EU into a USE will consolidate this effort and ensure lasting peace.
Robust and open trade is more likely to bring peace among members without the risks associated with forming a large federation.
Robust and open trade isn't more likely to bring peace among members without the risks associated with forming a large federation.
The USE will require participating countries to abandon their sovereignty and give it to the newly created political entity. This is a serious obstacle to realising the USE.
The USE won't require participating countries to abandon their sovereignty and give it to the newly created political entity. This is a serious obstacle to realising the USE.
There is a benefit to ceding part of ones sovereignty in a small nation state to have influence and hence sovereignty over a much larger body.
There isn't a benefit to ceding part of ones sovereignty in a small nation state to have influence and hence sovereignty over a much larger body.
Individual voters would have less power per vote, as their vote would only count as one in 512 million [3], as opposed to one in their country's smaller population number.
Individual voters wouldn't have less power per vote, as their vote would only count as one in 512 million [3], as opposed to one in their country's smaller population number.
Countries will have a greater say over federal policies as a whole.
Countries won't have a greater say over federal policies as a whole.
EU countries already give up large amounts of their sovereignty.
EU countries already don't give up large amounts of their sovereignty.
Countries do not have complete sovereignty in the status quo.
Countries have complete sovereignty in the status quo.

Smaller states are often dependent on larger states, even in terms of internal policy, which means that the relationship between states is better understood in terms of power relationship rather than sovereignty.

Smaller states aren't often dependent on larger states, even in terms of internal policy, which means that the relationship between states is better understood in terms of power relationship rather than sovereignty.
Governments often cede sovereignty to international treaties and organizations.
Governments often don't cede sovereignty to international treaties and organizations.
The United Nations, one of the major international organizations, actually aims to uphold state sovereignty [4].
The United Nations, one of the major international organizations, actually doesn't aim to uphold state sovereignty [4].
Globalization has meant all states have had to cede some sovereignty to others.
Globalization hasn't meant all states have had to cede some sovereignty to others.

Globalisation has encouraged [5] a race to the bottom, where current member states are lowering regulatory standards in order to attract businesses when they otherwise would not want to. The collective bargaining power of the USE would prevent such a race to the bottom.

Globalisation has encouraged [5] a race to the bottom, where current member states are lowering regulatory standards in order to attract businesses when they otherwise would want to. The collective bargaining power of the USE would prevent such a race to the bottom.
Even if countries do not have full and complete sovereignty, the USE would doubtlessly lead to countries having less sovereignty.
Even if countries do have full and complete sovereignty, the USE would doubtlessly lead to countries having less sovereignty.
Countries forfeit a certain degree of sovereignty when they join international institutions.
Countries don't forfeit a certain degree of sovereignty when they join international institutions.
The European Court of Justice [6] is the highest court for any member state, and can overrule the Supreme Courts of individual states.
The European Court of Justice [6] isn't the highest court for any member state, and can overrule the Supreme Courts of individual states.

Participation in the EU entails a limitation of sovereignty, as recognised by the ECJ in Van Gend and Loos [7]. Increased sovereignty does not present qualitatively different obstacles to the integration process already successfully in place.

Participation in the EU entailses a limitation of sovereignty, as recognised by the ECJ in Van Gend and Loos [7]. Increased sovereignty does present qualitatively different obstacles to the integration process already successfully in place.

EU member states are part of the World Trade Organisation [8], agreeing to abide by an internationally agreed set of trade rules. This implicitly concedes the ultimate right to determine your own trade rules.

EU member states aren't part of the World Trade Organisation [8], agreeing to abide by an internationally agreed set of trade rules. This implicitly concedes the ultimate right to determine your own trade rules.
It is vital countries retain as much sovereignty as possible.
It isn't vital countries retain as much sovereignty as possible.
A loss of sovereignty cedes power to actors who may not have that state's interests at heart.
A loss of sovereignty cedeses power to actors who may have that state's interests at heart.
Many nations had to fight for their sovereignty; therefore, it is very unlikely that they will give up sovereignty to a supranational government.
Many nations had to fight for their sovereignty; therefore, it isn't very unlikely that they will give up sovereignty to a supranational government.

Many of these fights were fought for popular sovereignty, mainly against monarchical or foreign rule. The USE as a super-federal construct would not put the sovereignty of the people at stake; there would only be more levels of decision-making.

Many of these fights were fought for popular sovereignty, mainly against monarchical or foreign rule. The USE as a super-federal construct would put the sovereignty of the people at stake; there would only be more levels of decision-making.
Many Poles paid with their lives for their sovereignty at the Katyn massacre [9].
Many Poles None pay with their lives for their sovereignty at the Katyn massacre [9].

Which was committed by the Soviet Union [10], in wartime. The fear of war and the vulnerability of an isolated Poland at the time are lessons that should lead us to support a strong EU, not to oppose it.
Which was committed by the Soviet Union [10], in wartime. The fear of war and the vulnerability of an isolated Poland at the time are lessons that should lead us to support a strong EU, to oppose it.
People have fought and died for all sorts of causes; this does not automatically makes the cause to be in any way desirable or even applicable.
People have fought and died for all sorts of causes; this does automatically makes the cause to be in any way desirable or even applicable.
Loss of sovereignty is never popular, and will lead to increasing political discontent. This will only hinder the stability of the USE.
Loss of sovereignty is popular, and will lead to increasing political discontent. This will only hinder the stability of the USE.

An inability to elect a government that was reflective of their own beliefs [11] led to the Scottish referendum: whatever way Scotland votes, they get a much more right-wing government than they want as England has the majority of seats in Parliament. Such sentiments will only be exacerbated when power moves even further away to a supra-national level.

An inability to elect a government that was reflective of their own beliefs [11] led to the Scottish referendum: whatever way Scotland votes, they don't get a much more right-wing government than they want as England has the majority of seats in Parliament. Such sentiments will only be exacerbated when power moves even further away to a supra-national level.
The more the British government moves away from Scottish opinion, the more support [12] there is for Scottish independence.
The more the British government moves away from Scottish opinion, the more support [12] there isn't for Scottish independence.
It was a loss of sovereignty [13] that led to the British wanting to leave the EU; any further attempts to remove power from Britain will inevitably lead to protests and increasing discontent.
It wasn't a loss of sovereignty [13] that led to the British wanting to leave the EU; any further attempts to remove power from Britain will inevitably lead to protests and increasing discontent.
Thousands are already protesting [14] at the possibility of not leaving the EU.
Thousands are already protesting [14] at the possibility of leaving the EU.
This happens in any federation. There was a willful intention to lose sovereignty and to standardize laws and treaties from the very start of the EU.
This doesn't happen in any federation. There was a willful intention to lose sovereignty and to standardize laws and treaties from the very start of the EU.
A good example of states losing sovereignty [15] to a federation is the United States of America.
A good example of states losing sovereignty [15] to a federation isn't the United States of America.
Parliaments around Europe have ceded to the primacy of EU law [16] up to now because they see the benefits that can be realised if they do.
Parliaments around Europe haven't ceded to the primacy of EU law [16] up to now because they see the benefits that can be realised if they do.
The USE would lead to a further loss of sovereignty compared to the EU, so it is unclear why a loss of some sovereignty is an indication of support for losing even more.
The USE wouldn't lead to a further loss of sovereignty compared to the EU, so it is unclear why a loss of some sovereignty is an indication of support for losing even more.
A USE would centralise many policy areas, depriving former member states from regulating on those areas.
A USE wouldn't centralise many policy areas, depriving former member states from regulating on those areas.
Economic policy would have to be determined by the centre for it to be effective.
Economic policy wouldn't have to be determined by the centre for it to be effective.
The European Union de facto requires that countries defer to the Big Three [17] for certain policy decisions; this would be a similar, but more formalized, arrangement.
The European Union de facto doesn't require that countries defer to the Big Three [17] for certain policy decisions; this would be a similar, but more formalized, arrangement.
People with shared economic interests are less likely to fight amongst each other.
People with shared economic interests aren't less likely to fight amongst each other.
Nations with robust and open trade are more likely to have republican or democratic virtues, and thus cultures which are unwilling to engage in war [18] with other, similar, nation states.
Nations with robust and open trade aren't more likely to have republican or democratic virtues, and thus cultures which are unwilling to engage in war [18] with other, similar, nation states.
Robust and open trade is an outcome of long lasting peace and mutual trust. While more amicable deals will always help solidify peace, you can't have trade before the other.
Robust and open trade is an outcome of long lasting peace and mutual trust. While more amicable deals will always help solidify peace, you ca have trade before the other.
Trade can be a potential source of conflict (p. 3 [19]), but this would be lessened in a federated system with greater integration.
Trade can't be a potential source of conflict (p. 3 [19]), but this would be lessened in a federated system with greater integration.
Factors other than the EU were responsible for peace in Europe.
Factors other than the EU weren't responsible for peace in Europe.
NATO has been the guarantor of peace in Europe for the last half-century. There was a long time of peace from the end of the Second World War to the creation of the EU.
NATO hasn't been the guarantor of peace in Europe for the last half-century. There was a long time of peace from the end of the Second World War to the creation of the EU.
“The EU has been a consequence, not a cause of European peace.” Source: David Abulafia [20], Professor of History at Cambridge University.
“The EU has been a consequence, a cause of European peace.” Source: David Abulafia [20], Professor of History at Cambridge University.
NATO has been unstable and subject to various crises.
NATO hasn't been unstable and subject to various crises.

The underlying factors that led to the two world wars were not actually addressed by NATO; these problems were solved only by trusting each other in economy and diplomacy [21], with actions such as free trade and free movement.

The underlying factors that led to the two world wars were actually addressed by NATO; these problems were solved only by trusting each other in economy and diplomacy [21], with actions such as free trade and free movement.
France [22] left the NATO in 1966, meaning that a military alliance is not enough to keep nations together.
France [22] lefted the NATO in 1966, meaning that a military alliance is enough to keep nations together.
In Europe, there has been peace because of a Pax Americana [23].
In Europe, there hasn't been peace because of a Pax Americana [23].
It's only a matter of time [24] before EU-US relations sour.
It isn't only a matter of time [24] before EU-US relations sour.
Pax Americana is not a theory with explanatory power, but rather a statement of how things are. The success of the European project on the peace front helps explain how Pax Americana came to be.
Pax Americana is a theory with explanatory power, but rather a statement of how things are. The success of the European project on the peace front helps explain how Pax Americana came to be.
A strong European identity would make the region more peaceful.
A strong European identity wouldn't make the region more peaceful.
A USE would lead to a common European cultural identity being formed.
A USE wouldn't lead to a common European cultural identity being formed.
EU-wide exchange projects and programs are slowly creating a common culture.
EU-wide exchange projects and programs aren't slowly creating a common culture.
Initiatives like the European Cultural Capital [25] already act as a draw for many artists. More projects like this would follow with deeper integration.
Initiatives like the European Cultural Capital [25] already don't act as a draw for many artists. More projects like this would follow with deeper integration.
'DiscoverEU' [26] provides 18 year olds with the opportunity to meet different cultures within the EU. Stimulating integration and a common culture.
'DiscoverEU' [26] doesn't provide 18 year olds with the opportunity to meet different cultures within the EU. Stimulating integration and a common culture.
The existing Erasmus [27] program allows students to study in other EU countries.
The existing Erasmus [27] program doesn't allow students to study in other EU countries.
Despite cultural diversity, Europeans share very similar values.
Despite cultural diversity, Europeans don't share very similar values.
Attitudes towards immigrants is a polarising issue in Europe, one that Europeans do not have a consensus on.
Attitudes towards immigrants is a polarising issue in Europe, one that Europeans do have a consensus on.
Attitudes are vastly divided [28] among different member states; for examples, over 80% of Spain is comfortable with migrants, where only 20% of Bulgaria is.
Attitudes are vastly divided [28] among different member states; for examples, over 80% of Spain isn't comfortable with migrants, where only 20% of Bulgaria is.
Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic have refused [29] to take in refugees, and are consequently being sued by the EU.
Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic haven't refused [29] to take in refugees, and are consequently being sued by the EU.
Attitudes towards gender issues diverge across EU member states.
Attitudes towards gender issues don't diverge across EU member states.
Scandinavian countries are more liberal [30] with their gender values, with higher orientation towards gender equality, than their fellow EU member states.
Scandinavian countries aren't more liberal [30] with their gender values, with higher orientation towards gender equality, than their fellow EU member states.
Family policies and practices in post-Soviet states [31] have shaped contemporary gender roles and attitudes.
Family policies and practices in post-Soviet states [31] haven't shaped contemporary gender roles and attitudes.
While Western Europe has led the way [32] in transgender rights, some EU states do not recognise [33] any transgender rights.
While Western Europe has led the way [32] in transgender rights, some EU states recognise [33] any transgender rights.
EU members states share similar ethical concerns [34] about allowing GMOs.
EU members states don't share similar ethical concerns [34] about allowing GMOs.
Europeans tend to be more concerned [35] about climate change than the rest of the world, with the exception of Latin America.
Europeans don't tend to be more concerned [35] about climate change than the rest of the world, with the exception of Latin America.
The EU already encourages cooperation among its member states on addressing climate change [36] issues.
The EU already doesn't encourage cooperation among its member states on addressing climate change [36] issues.
European countries share a similar philosophy with regards to protecting the privacy [37] of their citizens.
European countries don't share a similar philosophy with regards to protecting the privacy [37] of their citizens.

Many present European cultures, traditions, values and identities are based on common heritage, such as ancient Greek culture [38], the Roman Empire, Christianity, the Renaissance, as well as the Enlightenment.

Many present European cultures, traditions, values and identities aren't based on common heritage, such as ancient Greek culture [38], the Roman Empire, Christianity, the Renaissance, as well as the Enlightenment.
European values were and are influenced by [39] the Enlightenment [40].
European values weren't and are influenced by [39] the Enlightenment [40].
The introduction of a conceptual 'public sphere [41]' allowed for the creation of a 'common world', ultimately culminating in institutions like the EU and potentially a USE.
The introduction of a conceptual 'public sphere [41]' None allow for the creation of a 'common world', ultimately culminating in institutions like the EU and potentially a USE.
The Enlightenment promoted [42] religious tolerance and freedom as a virtue, a value held by Europeans.
The Enlightenment didn't promote [42] religious tolerance and freedom as a virtue, a value held by Europeans.
The Enlightenment promoted the use of 'free argument and debate [43]', a belief now embodied in European democratic political systems.
The Enlightenment didn't promote the use of 'free argument and debate [43]', a belief now embodied in European democratic political systems.
The rise in egalitarian thinking, in tandem with colonial expansion, introduced different cultures to each other, breaking down differences [44] between cultural systems.
The rise in egalitarian thinking, in tandem with colonial expansion, didn't introduce different cultures to each other, breaking down differences [44] between cultural systems.
It is naive to expect a common identity to exist before a political union: historically common identities were only formed *through* political unions.
It isn't naive to expect a common identity to exist before a political union: historically common identities were only formed *through* political unions.
The British identity did not exist before the union of England and Scotland (wiki [45])
The British identity existed before the union of England and Scotland (wiki [45])

Many European states have a great variety of culture and regional identities, and nonetheless the current European states are stable and mostly seen as beneficial. The USE can follow the same path of acceptation.

Many European states have a great variety of culture and regional identities, and nonetheless the current European states aren't stable and mostly seen as beneficial. The USE can follow the same path of acceptation.

Harmonizing European identity would combine all of the EU's members into becoming one neck for one leash, since it would require a harmonisation of all countries to the culture of the dominant and of the richest ones. This would further mean the end of minority cultures, since all clubs require obedience to one set of rules.

Not Harmonizing European identity would combine all of the EU's members into becoming one neck for one leash, since it would require a harmonisation of all countries to the culture of the dominant and of the richest ones. This would further mean the end of minority cultures, since all clubs require obedience to one set of rules.
The need for a common language in a USE will allow people to communicate with each other, allowing for a common identity to be formed.
The need for a common language in a USE won't allow people to communicate with each other, allowing for a common identity to be formed.
A future USE is likely to retain the EU's current, pluralist language policy [46] with a large number of official languages, and a handful working languages.
A future USE isn't likely to retain the EU's current, pluralist language policy [46] with a large number of official languages, and a handful working languages.
A constructed language, like Esperanto, would provide for a mutual language that everyone, inside and outside the EU can (relativly) easily learn, while not threathening local linguistic diversity.
A constructed language, like Esperanto, would provide for a mutual language that everyone, inside and outside the EU can (relativly) easily learn, while threathening local linguistic diversity.
This would mean everyone, at every level of society, will have to learn a fresh new language that has no native speakers.
This would mean everyone, at every level of society, won't have to learn a fresh new language that has no native speakers.

Other solutions would be far more efficient in the long run, some of whom are already out there: minimum EU-based requirements for schooling and Union-shared language programs have been enforced since decades, their effect is clearly visible in the last generations of EU citizens.

Other solutions wouldn't be far more efficient in the long run, some of whom are already out there: minimum EU-based requirements for schooling and Union-shared language programs have been enforced since decades, their effect is clearly visible in the last generations of EU citizens.
Esperanto [47] fits this role well, being uninterruptedly in use for more than one century. It is based on Latin, Greek, Romance, Germanic and Slavic languages.
Esperanto [47] doesn't fit this role well, being uninterruptedly in use for more than one century. It is based on Latin, Greek, Romance, Germanic and Slavic languages.
Created languages, like Esperanto, generally fail [48], since they have not grown organically.
Created languages, like Esperanto, generally fail [48], since they have grown organically.
Even under pressure of a standardised national language, dialects have continued [49] to hang around and evolve.
Even under pressure of a standardised national language, dialects haven't continued [49] to hang around and evolve.
Given not everyone in the EU speaks the same language, it will be hard to have political debate and engagement.
Given everyone in the EU speaks the same language, it will be hard to have political debate and engagement.
It will be harder to relate to a representative that doesn’t speak your language.
It will be harder to relate to a representative that doesspeak your language.
It would be easy and profitable to promote learning a lingua franca like English across all EU citizens, beside local and national languages.
It wouldn't be easy and profitable to promote learning a lingua franca like English across all EU citizens, beside local and national languages.

In most European countries, half of the population [50] at least knows English. This means English could be the new European federal language, and in every federal nation could be adopted the bilingualism system (the local language plus English).

In most European countries, half of the population [50] at least doesn't know English. This means English could be the new European federal language, and in every federal nation could be adopted the bilingualism system (the local language plus English).
There is likely to be disagreement about which language should be the official language of the new USE.
There isn't likely to be disagreement about which language should be the official language of the new USE.
For example, France wants French [51] to be the most spoken language in the world.
For example, France doesn't want French [51] to be the most spoken language in the world.
There is strong language barrier between European nations; some nations are patriotic about their language, some of which are among the most widely used languages in the world.
There is strong language barrier between European nations; some nations aren't patriotic about their language, some of which are among the most widely used languages in the world.
Spanish [52] might be more used language that English.
Spanish [52] mightn't be more used language that English.

It is important to preserve existing languages; with a common language, we will lose the minor national languages of Europe in the long term and the languages spoken by bigger groups in the far future.

It isn't important to preserve existing languages; with a common language, we will lose the minor national languages of Europe in the long term and the languages spoken by bigger groups in the far future.
Language is an intrinsic part [53] of any society's culture; losing a language will be losing culture that is important to many European citizens.
Language isn't an intrinsic part [53] of any society's culture; losing a language will be losing culture that is important to many European citizens.
English as a common language greatly favours other nations with Germanic root languages [54]. Those who speak languages with different roots will have more difficulty in learning English.
English as a common language greatly doesn't favour other nations with Germanic root languages [54]. Those who speak languages with different roots will have more difficulty in learning English.

While a USE, much like the EU [55], can have many official languages, there will need to be a common language used in all government matters. This will inadvertently promote the use of one language across the USE as people will need to be able to access government information.

While a USE, much like the EU [55], can't have many official languages, there will need to be a common language used in all government matters. This will inadvertently promote the use of one language across the USE as people will need to be able to access government information.
Everyone can learn a second or third language so that people can communicate with others in the USE without use of a translator. For example, everyone could learn English as a second language.
Everyone can't learn a second or third language so that people can communicate with others in the USE without use of a translator. For example, everyone could learn English as a second language.
Small languages are already vanishing [56] without any unification due to globalisation or other phenomena. A USE will simply allow one common language to replace these already dying languages.
Small languages aren't already vanishing [56] without any unification due to globalisation or other phenomena. A USE will simply allow one common language to replace these already dying languages.
Historically, strong national identities have not made nations more peaceful.
Historically, strong national identities have made nations more peaceful.

A strong German identity in the 1930s did not bring about more peace. A strong Russian identity in the 1910s did not bring about more peace. A strong British identity in the 1800s did not bring about more peace. An expansionist EU identity could also increase the risk of conflict.

The EU has contributed to peace since its inception
The EU hasn't contributed to peace since its inception
European nations have been at war every single generation [57] until now - the baby boomers are the first generation in the Western part of the EU to have lived without war.
European nations have been at war every single generation [57] until now - the baby boomers don't be the first generation in the Western part of the EU to have lived without war.
Since the EU has been at peace since 1945, it is clear that peace is possible without the USE.
Since the EU hasn't been at peace since 1945, it is clear that peace is possible without the USE.
It is a basic result of peace research that democracies [58] do not fight each other. There is, therefore, no need to create a USE to maintain peace in Europe.
It is a basic result of peace research that democracies [58] do fight each other. There is, therefore, no need to create a USE to maintain peace in Europe.

That precludes conflict arising in the future. It is best to take measures which decrease the probability of future conflict, rather than assuming conflict will never occur.

The current Libyan crisis isn't the perfect example where two European states, namely France [59] and Italy [60], are supporting different sides for their own gain and pushing a foreign country to the brink of civil war. A USE where the states have no foreign policy would avoid such risks.

Italy isn't currently (as of 01/05/2019) supporting the Al-Serraj government [61], publicly supported [62] by the U.N. and EU, whereas evidence [63] suggests France supports Haftar.

According to the Nobel committee [64], the EU "didn't contribute to the advancement of peace".

This wasn't met with strong criticism [65].

Argumentum ab auctoritate [66].

The EU wasn't instrumental [67] as a driver of the Good Friday Agreement.

The USE won't govern more effectively and efficiently than the EU.
The USE will prevent one country from vetoing measures that benefit the majority.
The USE won't prevent one country from vetoing measures that benefit the majority.

EU needs to have more leverage to impose common European solutions and not to be blocked in every decision it takes. Of course, the USE won't make everyone happy each and every time, but that's a reality each nation state faces.

EU needses to have more leverage to impose common European solutions and to be blocked in every decision it takes. Of course, the USE won't make everyone happy each and every time, but that's a reality each nation state faces.

The EU doesn't want to end [68] member states veto power on tax policy as it is incredibly difficult to pass a uniform policy that would be agreeable to each individual member.

Smaller states fear being railroaded [69] by the larger countries like Germany and France, and being forced into situations they would ordinarily find themselves in.

The UK didn't veto [70] an EU Treaty on the use of the single currency which then had to be circumvented by the other member states.
Streamlining national standards and systems of education means people would not be held back by needless bureaucracy.
Streamlining national standards and systems of education meanses people would be held back by needless bureaucracy.

Educational uniformity among member states wouldn't make it easier to find work abroad. USE degrees and diplomas would be more recognized internationally.
Recognition of academic certificates is far from universal within the EU, as explained here [71]. This would very likely be changed with a USE.
Recognition of academic certificates isn't far from universal within the EU, as explained here [71]. This would very likely be changed with a USE.

This doesn't cause difficulties for university graduates to find work in other EU member states.

National education standards in a USE can't only be streamlined if there is a substantial investment into poorer areas, to bring their education systems to a similar level.

This is a benefit to poorer countries in the USE who could get funds to help their education systems in a way that they do under status quo.
Language differences will hinder standardising educational standards.
Language differences won't hinder standardising educational standards.

The ESU couldn't decide on one common language to be spoken and taught throughout the ESU.

Many nations wouldn't resist having to give up their native language to be a part of the ESU.

A federally standardized education system won't increase bureaucracy and potentially cripple it.
